hints.content: Let's try each set of groups to see whether it equals $21$ cars.

###$3$ groups of $7$ cars

![3 groups of 7 cars](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/98d58ae50df4d4d99b4fd0f3721157b44d35efb8)

$7+7+7=21$ , so Jen can group her cars this way.

###$7$ groups of $3$ cars

![7 groups of 3 cars](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9fec4cb33f28f50c87a54e548c6de356ed5c6591)

$3+3+3+3+3+3+3=21$ , so Jen can group her cars this way.

###$4$ groups of $5$ cars

![4 groups of 5 cars](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/58386d1250d0cddc0e71a9b22398f3e4791d26a8)

$5+5+5+5=20$ , so Jen **cannot** group her $21$ cars this way.

###$2$ groups of $10$ cars

![2 groups of 10 cars](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/f0d82d4af278e55d27e2204bd92e56214a628faf)

$10+10=20$ , so Jen **cannot** group her $21$ cars this way.

Jen can groups her cars these ways:

- $3$ groups of $7$ cars
- $7$ groups of $3$ cars

[[☃ explanation 1]]

question.content:
Jen has $21$ toy cars.

**What are two ways Jen can group her cars?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: This would be $20$ cars instead of $21$ cars.
This would be $20$ cars instead of $21$ cars.
